title: Mark Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Mark chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Mark Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Mark Chapter 2.

questions.question: Where did Jesus enter after some days according to Mark 2:1?
options: Capernaum
Jerusalem
Bethlehem
Nazareth
questions.correctAnswer: Capernaum
questions.explanation: Mark 2:1 states that Jesus entered into Capernaum after some days.

questions.question: What prevented the people from coming near Jesus with the sick man in Mark 2:4?
options: The crowd pressing around
A locked door
A river
A mountain
questions.correctAnswer: The crowd pressing around
questions.explanation: Mark 2:4 explains that they could not come nigh unto Jesus for the press (crowd).

questions.question: Who was brought to Jesus by four men in Mark 2:3?
options: A sick of the palsy
A blind man
A deaf man
A leper
questions.correctAnswer: A sick of the palsy
questions.explanation: Mark 2:3 says they brought one sick of the palsy borne of four men.

questions.question: What did Jesus say to the sick of the palsy in Mark 2:5?
options: Son, thy sins be forgiven thee
Arise and walk
Be healed in the name of God
Peace be unto you
questions.correctAnswer: Son, thy sins be forgiven thee
questions.explanation: Mark 2:5 reports Jesus saying, 'Son, thy sins be forgiven thee' when He saw their faith.

questions.question: Who reasoned in their hearts that only God can forgive sins according to Mark 2:7?
options: Scribes
Pharisees
Disciples
Romans
questions.correctAnswer: Scribes
questions.explanation: Mark 2:7 says certain scribes were reasoning in their hearts about Jesus forgiving sins.

questions.question: What question did Jesus ask about forgiving sins or healing the sick man in Mark 2:9?
options: Which is easier to say, 'Thy sins be forgiven' or 'Take up thy bed and walk'?
Who can forgive sins?
Why do you judge?
Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath?
questions.correctAnswer: Which is easier to say, 'Thy sins be forgiven' or 'Take up thy bed and walk'?
questions.explanation: Mark 2:9 quotes Jesus asking which is easier to say to the sick of the palsy.

questions.question: What did Jesus command the sick man to do after forgiving his sins in Mark 2:11?
options: Arise, take up thy bed, and go into thine house
Sit still and rest
Go to the temple
Tell no man
questions.correctAnswer: Arise, take up thy bed, and go into thine house
questions.explanation: Mark 2:11 records Jesus telling the man to arise, take up his bed, and go home.

questions.question: Who did Jesus call to follow Him while sitting at the receipt of custom in Mark 2:14?
options: Levi the son of Alphaeus
Peter
John
Matthew the tax collector
questions.correctAnswer: Levi the son of Alphaeus
questions.explanation: Mark 2:14 says Jesus saw Levi son of Alphaeus and said to him, 'Follow me.'

questions.question: Who were sitting together with Jesus and his disciples at meat according to Mark 2:15?
options: Publicans and sinners
Pharisees
Roman soldiers
Sadducees
questions.correctAnswer: Publicans and sinners
questions.explanation: Mark 2:15 describes many publicans and sinners sitting with Jesus and His disciples.

questions.question: What reason did Jesus give for eating with publicans and sinners in Mark 2:17?
options: The sick need a physician, not the whole
To show His power
To follow the law
To condemn sinners
questions.correctAnswer: The sick need a physician, not the whole
questions.explanation: Mark 2:17 quotes Jesus saying He came to call sinners to repentance, like a physician for the sick.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said that the disciples of John and Pharisees fasted more than His disciples, according to Mark 2:18.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Mark 2:18 states that disciples of John and Pharisees used to fast, but Jesus' disciples did not at that time.

questions.question: True or False: According to Mark 2:27, the Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Mark 2:27 clearly states that the Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said He is Lord of the Sabbath according to Mark 2:28.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Mark 2:28 says the Son of man is Lord also of the Sabbath.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Mark 2:22: 'No man putteth new wine into old bottles: else the new wine doth burst the bottles, and the wine is spilled, and the bottles will be marred: but new wine must be put into ______.'
options: new bottles
old bottles
leather bags
earthen jars
questions.correctAnswer: new bottles
questions.explanation: Mark 2:22 explains that new wine must be put into new bottles to avoid bursting them.

questions.question: What did Jesus' disciples do while going through the corn fields on the Sabbath day according to Mark 2:23?
options: Plucked ears of corn
Prayed silently
Rested
Sang hymns
questions.correctAnswer: Plucked ears of corn
questions.explanation: Mark 2:23 states that the disciples began to pluck the ears of corn as they went through the fields on the Sabbath.

medium.title: Mark Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Mark Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about forgiveness. Based on Mark 2:5-7, what biblical truth would you share about faith and forgiveness?
options: Faith is necessary to receive forgiveness, which only God can grant.
Forgiveness is earned by works and obedience only.
Only priests can forgive sins.
Forgiveness is unrelated to faith and is automatic.
questions.correctAnswer: Faith is necessary to receive forgiveness, which only God can grant.
questions.explanation: Mark 2:5 shows Jesus forgiving the sick of the palsy because of faith, and Mark 2:7 affirms that only God can forgive sins, highlighting the need for faith in God's forgiveness.

questions.question: How does Mark 2:14-15 teach about evangelism and responding to Jesus' call?
options: We should immediately follow Jesus when He calls, just as Levi did.
We should first finish our work before following Jesus.
Following Jesus is optional based on personal convenience.
Evangelism is only for church leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: We should immediately follow Jesus when He calls, just as Levi did.
questions.explanation: In Mark 2:14, Levi immediately arose and followed Jesus when called, demonstrating prompt obedience in evangelism and discipleship, which is reinforced by the gathering of sinners in Mark 2:15.

questions.question: A believer wonders why Jesus ate with sinners. What does Mark 2:16-17 teach about Jesus' mission and compassion?
options: Jesus came to call sinners to repentance, not the righteous.
Jesus avoided sinners to keep His reputation.
Eating with sinners was a social mistake.
Only Pharisees were worthy of Jesus' company.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus came to call sinners to repentance, not the righteous.
questions.explanation: Mark 2:17 clearly states that Jesus' mission was to call sinners to repentance, showing His compassion and purpose in associating with those considered outcasts.

questions.question: How does Mark 2:18-20 provide insight into spiritual disciplines like fasting?
options: Fasting is appropriate when the bridegroom (Jesus) is absent, symbolizing times of spiritual longing.
Fasting is required daily regardless of circumstances.
Fasting is only for Pharisees and John’s disciples.
Fasting is an outdated practice with no spiritual significance.
questions.correctAnswer: Fasting is appropriate when the bridegroom (Jesus) is absent, symbolizing times of spiritual longing.
questions.explanation: Jesus explains in Mark 2:19-20 that fasting is not fitting while He, the bridegroom, is present, but will be appropriate after His departure, teaching the timing and purpose of spiritual disciplines.

questions.question: A church leader asks how to maintain spiritual integrity in new teachings. What wisdom does Mark 2:21-22 offer?
options: New teachings must be embraced with new hearts, just as new wine needs new bottles.
Old traditions should never change under any circumstance.
Mixing old and new teachings is always beneficial.
New teachings should replace old ones without consideration.
questions.correctAnswer: New teachings must be embraced with new hearts, just as new wine needs new bottles.
questions.explanation: Mark 2:21-22 uses the metaphor of new cloth and new wine with old garments and bottles to teach that spiritual renewal requires a newness of heart and mindset to preserve integrity and effectiveness.

questions.question: Based on Mark 2:23-28, how should Christians understand the relationship between religious rules and human needs?
options: The Sabbath was made to serve people’s needs, emphasizing mercy over rigid rules.
Religious rules must always be followed regardless of circumstances.
Human needs are less important than religious traditions.
Sabbath laws are irrelevant today.
questions.correctAnswer: The Sabbath was made to serve people’s needs, emphasizing mercy over rigid rules.
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches in Mark 2:27 that the Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath, highlighting the priority of human well-being and mercy within religious observance.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged in prayer and faith. How does the story of the paralyzed man in Mark 2:1-12 encourage perseverance and trust in God’s power?
options: Faith and persistence, like those who lowered the man through the roof, can lead to miraculous healing and forgiveness.
God only answers prayers instantly without delay.
Healing depends on social status, not faith.
Miracles are rare and only for the apostles.
questions.correctAnswer: Faith and persistence, like those who lowered the man through the roof, can lead to miraculous healing and forgiveness.
questions.explanation: Mark 2:3-5 shows the friends’ faith and effort to bring the paralyzed man to Jesus, resulting in forgiveness and healing, encouraging believers to persist in faith and prayer.

questions.question: True or False: According to Mark 2:28, Jesus claims authority over the Sabbath, indicating His lordship over religious law.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Mark 2:28 states that the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath, affirming Jesus' authority over religious laws and practices.

questions.question: True or False: Mark 2:6-8 shows that Jesus was unaware of the scribes’ thoughts questioning His authority to forgive sins.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Mark 2:8 says Jesus immediately perceived in His spirit what the scribes were reasoning, showing His awareness of their doubts.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Mark 2:27 teaches that the ______ was made for man, and not man for the ______.
options: Sabbath, sabbath
Law, law
Temple, temple
Sacrifice, sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: Sabbath, sabbath
questions.explanation: Mark 2:27 clearly states, 'The sabbath was made for man, and not man for the sabbath,' emphasizing the purpose of the Sabbath for human benefit.

questions.question: How does Mark 2:11-12 demonstrate the importance of public testimony in faith and healing?
options: The healed man walked before all, leading many to glorify God and be amazed.
Healing should always be private and hidden.
Faith is personal and does not require public acknowledgment.
Only the disciples should witness miracles.
questions.correctAnswer: The healed man walked before all, leading many to glorify God and be amazed.
questions.explanation: Mark 2:11-12 shows Jesus commanding the man to rise and walk publicly, resulting in amazement and glorification of God among witnesses, underscoring testimony's role in faith.

questions.question: According to Mark 2:23-24, what biblical principle is illustrated when Jesus’ disciples pluck ears of corn on the Sabbath?
options: Human need can take precedence over ceremonial law.
The Sabbath law prohibits any work under any condition.
Disciples should avoid all activities on the Sabbath.
Only Pharisees understand Sabbath laws correctly.
questions.correctAnswer: Human need can take precedence over ceremonial law.
questions.explanation: Mark 2:23-24 shows the Pharisees questioning the disciples, but Jesus later explains that human need justifies certain actions, teaching mercy over strict legalism.

questions.question: What does Mark 2:4 teach about the role of community and helping others in spiritual healing?
options: The friends’ faith and determination to bring the paralytic to Jesus shows the power of community support in healing.
Healing is a solo journey with no need for others.
Only the sick can seek their own healing without help.
Community involvement is a distraction from faith.
questions.correctAnswer: The friends’ faith and determination to bring the paralytic to Jesus shows the power of community support in healing.
questions.explanation: Mark 2:4 describes how the friends broke the roof to lower the paralytic to Jesus, demonstrating active community involvement in spiritual restoration.

questions.question: How does Mark 2:13-14 illustrate the importance of evangelism in everyday life?
options: Jesus called Levi, a tax collector, demonstrating that evangelism reaches all kinds of people in ordinary settings.
Evangelism should only occur in religious buildings.
Only the religious elite are called to evangelize.
Evangelism is not necessary in secular places.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus called Levi, a tax collector, demonstrating that evangelism reaches all kinds of people in ordinary settings.
questions.explanation: Mark 2:13-14 shows Jesus engaging and calling Levi from his workplace, emphasizing that evangelism is a personal call extended in daily life to all people.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility and gratitude can be drawn from the reaction of the crowd in Mark 2:12?
options: The crowd was amazed and glorified God, showing how witnessing God's work leads to gratitude and humility.
The crowd ignored the miracle and remained indifferent.
Pride is encouraged when witnessing miracles.
Gratitude is only for personal blessings, not others’ healing.
questions.correctAnswer: The crowd was amazed and glorified God, showing how witnessing God's work leads to gratitude and humility.
questions.explanation: Mark 2:12 describes the crowd’s amazement and glorifying God after the healing, illustrating how such experiences foster humility and thankfulness.

hard.title: Mark Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Mark Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Mark 2:5, Jesus forgives the sins of the paralytic. Which Old Testament concept does this act most directly challenge according to Mark’s audience?
options: Only God can forgive sins, reflecting monotheistic belief
Sin is always forgiven through temple sacrifices
Forgiveness is granted by the priests alone
Sins are forgiven only on the Day of Atonement
questions.correctAnswer: Only God can forgive sins, reflecting monotheistic belief
questions.explanation: Mark 2:7 shows scribes reasoning that only God can forgive sins, highlighting Jewish monotheistic theology which Jesus challenges by forgiving sins himself.

questions.question: The lowering of the paralytic through the roof in Mark 2:4 can be seen as an example of what literary device?
options: Chiasmus, showing the reversal of barriers
Typology, foreshadowing Jesus’ ability to break spiritual barriers
Metonymy, using roof for house
Allegory of faith and salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Typology, foreshadowing Jesus’ ability to break spiritual barriers
questions.explanation: The removal of the roof symbolizes breaking obstacles to access Jesus, typologically representing spiritual access to forgiveness (Mark 2:4).

questions.question: What Greek term underlies the phrase 'Son of man' in Mark 2:10, and what is its significance in Jewish apocalyptic literature?
options: ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου (ho huios tou anthrōpou), denoting a Messianic figure with authority
Μεσσίας (Messias), meaning the anointed king
Δούλος (Doulos), meaning servant
Ποιμήν (Poimēn), meaning shepherd
questions.correctAnswer: ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου (ho huios tou anthrōpou), denoting a Messianic figure with authority
questions.explanation: The phrase 'Son of man' (Mark 2:10) echoes Daniel 7:13-14's apocalyptic figure endowed with authority, highlighting Jesus' divine authority to forgive sins.

questions.question: In Mark 2:14, Jesus calls Levi the son of Alphaeus to follow Him. Levi is also known by what other name, and what is the significance of this in the Gospels?
options: Matthew, emphasizing a tax collector’s call to discipleship
Judas, symbolizing betrayal
Simon, representing the foundation of the church
James, linking to the Twelve Apostles
questions.correctAnswer: Matthew, emphasizing a tax collector’s call to discipleship
questions.explanation: Levi is identified as Matthew, the tax collector called by Jesus, illustrating the theme of calling sinners to repentance (Mark 2:14).

questions.question: The Pharisees’ objection in Mark 2:16 about Jesus eating with publicans and sinners reflects what cultural norm in Second Temple Judaism?
options: Purity laws forbidding association with sinners
The requirement to fast on certain days
Sabbath restrictions on work
The prohibition of eating with Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Purity laws forbidding association with sinners
questions.explanation: Pharisees viewed eating with sinners as defiling, which Jesus counters by emphasizing his mission to call sinners to repentance (Mark 2:16-17).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of Jesus identifying Himself as 'Lord of the Sabbath' in Mark 2:28?
options: He claims authority over Mosaic Law and its interpretation
He declares the Sabbath abolished
He indicates he will create a new Sabbath
He aligns himself with Roman authority
questions.correctAnswer: He claims authority over Mosaic Law and its interpretation
questions.explanation: By saying He is Lord of the Sabbath (Mark 2:28), Jesus asserts His divine authority to interpret the Law, emphasizing mercy over legalism.

questions.question: The analogy of new wine and old wineskins in Mark 2:22 serves to illustrate which theological principle?
options: New teachings require new frameworks, not old traditionalism
Old traditions are superior to new teachings
Wine is symbolic of God’s wrath
The incompatibility of Jewish and Gentile believers
questions.correctAnswer: New teachings require new frameworks, not old traditionalism
questions.explanation: Jesus uses the metaphor to show that His new message cannot be contained in old legalistic structures (Mark 2:22).

questions.question: In Mark 2:18-20, Jesus uses the metaphor of the bridegroom and the children of the bridechamber. What does this metaphor indicate about the timing of fasting in relation to His ministry?
options: Fasting is inappropriate while Jesus (the bridegroom) is present, but will be appropriate after He is taken away
Fasting is unnecessary for all time
Only John’s disciples should fast
Fasting replaces the sabbath observance
questions.correctAnswer: Fasting is inappropriate while Jesus (the bridegroom) is present, but will be appropriate after He is taken away
questions.explanation: Jesus explains that fasting will occur after His departure, showing the transitional nature of His presence (Mark 2:19-20).

questions.question: Mark 2:27 states, 'The sabbath was made for man, and not man for the sabbath.' How does this statement reflect a broader biblical theme found in the Old Testament?
options: The Law is meant to serve human well-being, not to be burdensome
The sabbath is the most important commandment
Man must obey the sabbath strictly
The sabbath is only for priests
questions.correctAnswer: The Law is meant to serve human well-being, not to be burdensome
questions.explanation: This principle aligns with the spirit of the Law focusing on mercy and care for humans (see Hosea 6:6), emphasizing purpose over ritual (Mark 2:27).

questions.question: The healing of the paralytic in Mark 2:11-12 is a narrative foreshadowing of which broader Christological theme?
options: Jesus’ authority to forgive sins and heal both body and soul
Jesus’ role as a political messiah overthrowing Rome
Jesus’ emphasis on dietary laws
Jesus’ rejection of Pharisaic traditions
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus’ authority to forgive sins and heal both body and soul
questions.explanation: The healing demonstrates Jesus’ power to forgive sins and restore physical health, a sign of his messianic identity (Mark 2:11-12).

questions.question: The scribes’ internal reasoning in Mark 2:6-7 about Jesus’ words is an example of what literary and theological motif?
options: Blasphemy accusation reflecting Jewish expectations of divine prerogative
Prophetic fulfillment
Messianic secret motif
Parable of the sower
questions.correctAnswer: Blasphemy accusation reflecting Jewish expectations of divine prerogative
questions.explanation: Their thoughts accuse Jesus of blasphemy because only God can forgive sins, reflecting Jewish monotheistic belief (Mark 2:6-7).

questions.question: Which Old Testament event does Jesus reference in Mark 2:25-26 to justify his disciples' actions on the Sabbath?
options: David eating the consecrated bread at Nob
Moses striking the rock for water
Elijah’s provision by ravens
The anointing of King Saul
questions.correctAnswer: David eating the consecrated bread at Nob
questions.explanation: Jesus cites David’s eating of the shewbread, which was lawful only for priests, to show mercy and human need override sabbath rules (Mark 2:25-26).

questions.question: True or False: According to Mark 2:23-24, the Pharisees approved of Jesus’ disciples plucking ears of corn on the sabbath.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Pharisees challenged Jesus for allowing disciples to do what they considered unlawful on the sabbath (Mark 2:24).

questions.question: In the context of Mark 2, how does Jesus’ interaction with the tax collectors and sinners contribute to the theme of the Kingdom of God in the Synoptic Gospels?
options: It emphasizes inclusion and the call to repentance for all, especially the marginalized
It suggests a political revolution against Rome
It focuses solely on ritual purity
It promotes strict adherence to Jewish law
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes inclusion and the call to repentance for all, especially the marginalized
questions.explanation: Jesus’ eating with sinners highlights the Kingdom’s openness to repentant sinners, a key theme in Mark (Mark 2:15-17).

questions.question: What is the significance of the crowd’s reaction in Mark 2:12 after the paralytic is healed?
options: They glorify God, showing amazement and recognition of divine authority
They reject Jesus as a blasphemer
They ignore the miracle and continue their activities
They immediately arrest Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: They glorify God, showing amazement and recognition of divine authority
questions.explanation: The crowd's glorification of God reflects recognition of Jesus’ divine power (Mark 2:12).

theological.title: Mark Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Mark Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Mark 2, what authority does Jesus demonstrate that causes amazement among the people?
options: Authority to forgive sins and heal the paralytic
Authority to cast out demons only
Authority to preach the law
Authority to perform miracles only
questions.correctAnswer: Authority to forgive sins and heal the paralytic
questions.explanation: In Mark 2:5-12, Jesus forgives the sins of the paralytic and then heals him, demonstrating divine authority. This authority to forgive sins is unique to God (Mark 2:7), affirming His deity and messianic role. Similar authority is seen in Isaiah 43:25 and Psalm 103:3, where God forgives sins and heals. Jesus' authority both reveals His divine identity and the new covenant reality.

questions.question: Why did the scribes accuse Jesus of blasphemy in Mark 2?
options: Because He claimed to forgive sins, which only God can do
Because He healed on the Sabbath
Because He ate with sinners
Because He taught with authority
questions.correctAnswer: Because He claimed to forgive sins, which only God can do
questions.explanation: Mark 2:6-7 records scribes reasoning that forgiving sins is blasphemy since only God can forgive sins. This highlights the divine prerogative of forgiveness (Psalm 130:4; Isaiah 43:25). Jesus' claim affirms His divine nature, linking to the Old Testament understanding of God's unique authority to forgive.

questions.question: What was the faith response of those who brought the paralytic to Jesus in Mark 2?
options: They broke the roof and lowered him down to Jesus
They asked Jesus to pray for him quietly
They waited patiently outside the house
They carried him away after Jesus left
questions.correctAnswer: They broke the roof and lowered him down to Jesus
questions.explanation: Mark 2:3-4 describes how the friends, unable to reach Jesus due to the crowd, removed part of the roof to lower the paralytic. Their bold action exemplifies persistent faith, trusting Jesus’ power and compassion. This mirrors the persistent faith theme seen in Luke 11:5-10 and Hebrews 11.

questions.question: In Mark 2, what is the significance of Jesus calling Levi (Matthew) to follow Him?
options: It shows Jesus calling sinners to repentance and discipleship
It emphasizes Jesus’ exclusive ministry to Jews only
It demonstrates the importance of tax collectors in society
It highlights the need for financial support for Jesus’ ministry
questions.correctAnswer: It shows Jesus calling sinners to repentance and discipleship
questions.explanation: Mark 2:14 shows Jesus calling Levi, a tax collector, to follow Him. This highlights the gospel's call to sinners into repentance and discipleship, consistent with Luke 19:10 and 1 Timothy 1:15. Jesus’ ministry breaks social and religious barriers to extend grace and salvation.

questions.question: How does Jesus explain His association with 'publicans and sinners' in Mark 2?
options: He came to call sinners to repentance, not the righteous
He wanted to criticize their lifestyle
He was unaware of their status
He was attempting to convert Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: He came to call sinners to repentance, not the righteous
questions.explanation: Mark 2:17 records Jesus saying He came not to call the righteous but sinners to repentance. This emphasizes His mission of salvation and grace for the lost, fulfilling Old Testament prophecies like Isaiah 61:1 and Ezekiel 34:16 about God's care for the marginalized.

questions.question: What theological principle about the Sabbath does Jesus teach in Mark 2?
options: The Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath
The Sabbath must be observed with strict legalism
The Sabbath is only for priests
The Sabbath is no longer necessary
questions.correctAnswer: The Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath
questions.explanation: Mark 2:27 states the Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath. This principle highlights God's intention for the Sabbath to serve human need and well-being rather than human burdens. This aligns with Exodus 20:8-11 and Hosea 6:6, emphasizing mercy over ritual.

questions.question: What eschatological title does Jesus claim for Himself in relation to the Sabbath in Mark 2?
options: Son of man is Lord also of the Sabbath
Son of David is King of Israel
Son of God is Judge of all
Messiah is Servant of Hosts
questions.correctAnswer: Son of man is Lord also of the Sabbath
questions.explanation: Mark 2:28 declares the Son of man is Lord of the Sabbath, affirming Jesus' messianic authority and divine lordship. This title connects to Daniel 7:13-14 and Psalm 110:1, affirming His eschatological role and authority over creation and law.

questions.question: How does Jesus use the metaphor of new cloth and old garments in Mark 2?
options: To illustrate the incompatibility of old and new covenants
To teach about the importance of clothing the poor
To explain the restoration of the Levitical priesthood
To describe the physical healing process
questions.correctAnswer: To illustrate the incompatibility of old and new covenants
questions.explanation: Mark 2:21 uses the metaphor of new cloth on an old garment to show that the new covenant in Christ cannot be patched onto the old Mosaic system without conflict. This illustrates the radical nature of Christ’s new covenant (Hebrews 8:13, Jeremiah 31:31-34).

questions.question: In Mark 2, what does Jesus say about putting new wine into old bottles?
options: New wine must be put into new bottles to avoid bursting
Old bottles are stronger and can contain new wine
New wine can be stored in any container
Old wine is better than new wine
questions.correctAnswer: New wine must be put into new bottles to avoid bursting
questions.explanation: Mark 2:22 teaches that new wine must be put into new bottles, symbolizing that the new covenant requires a new framework and mindset. This aligns with the renewal of the heart in Ezekiel 36:26 and 2 Corinthians 5:17.

questions.question: What Old Testament event does Jesus reference to justify His disciples plucking grain on the Sabbath?
options: David eating the showbread when hungry
Moses receiving the Ten Commandments
Elijah being fed by ravens
Jonah being in the fish
questions.correctAnswer: David eating the showbread when hungry
questions.explanation: In Mark 2:25-26, Jesus cites David eating the consecrated showbread, which was lawful only for priests, to illustrate mercy and human need superseding ceremonial law. This event is recorded in 1 Samuel 21:1-6 and shows Jesus’ teaching on Sabbath law’s intended purpose.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Son of man' as used by Jesus in Mark 2?
options: It affirms His messianic identity and divine authority
It is a common term for a Jewish teacher
It means He is a son of a carpenter
It refers to a prophet like Elijah
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms His messianic identity and divine authority
questions.explanation: Jesus uses 'Son of man' in Mark 2:10 and 2:28 to claim the messianic title from Daniel 7:13-14, expressing both humanity and divine authority. This term emphasizes the fulfillment of prophecy and His role in salvation history.

questions.question: How does Mark 2 portray the relationship between faith and healing?
options: Faith is essential for Jesus to act in healing
Healing happens independent of faith
Only the sick can have faith
Faith is irrelevant to miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Faith is essential for Jesus to act in healing
questions.explanation: Mark 2:5 shows Jesus forgiving the paralytic's sins because He saw their faith, indicating faith’s essential role in receiving healing. This theme is consistent with James 5:15 and Matthew 9:22, where faith activates divine healing.

questions.question: What does Jesus imply about fasting during His presence in Mark 2?
options: Fasting is inappropriate while the bridegroom is with them
Fasting is mandatory every day
Fasting was abolished completely
Fasting is only for Pharisees
questions.correctAnswer: Fasting is inappropriate while the bridegroom is with them
questions.explanation: Mark 2:19 uses the bridegroom metaphor to explain that fasting is not fitting while Jesus (the bridegroom) is present, highlighting joy and celebration in His ministry. This anticipates future fasting after His departure (Mark 2:20) and aligns with Isaiah 61:3’s theme of joy replacing mourning.

questions.question: What does Mark 2 teach about Jesus' mission in relation to sinners and the righteous?
options: He came to call sinners to repentance, not the self-righteous
He came to establish a new law for the righteous
He came to condemn sinners publicly
He came only to heal the sick physically
questions.correctAnswer: He came to call sinners to repentance, not the self-righteous
questions.explanation: In Mark 2:17, Jesus states His mission is to call sinners to repentance, emphasizing grace and restoration rather than condemnation. This is consistent with Luke 5:32 and 1 Timothy 1:15, highlighting the gospel's redemptive focus.

questions.question: What does Jesus demonstrate by healing the paralytic in the presence of scribes in Mark 2?
options: His authority to forgive sins and perform miracles, affirming His divine identity
His power to perform only physical healings
His willingness to avoid conflict with religious leaders
His role as a political revolutionary
questions.correctAnswer: His authority to forgive sins and perform miracles, affirming His divine identity
questions.explanation: Mark 2:8-12 shows Jesus perceiving the scribes’ thoughts and healing the paralytic to prove His authority to forgive sins, which only God possesses. This act confirms His deity and messianic mission, consistent with Psalm 103:3 and Isaiah 53:5.
